conclusion: A fixed smooth curved track smoothly connects with a smooth horizontal ground at point O.
A smooth inclined plane C with mass 3m is placed stationary on the ground.
A small block A with mass m starts from rest at a height h and slides down the track.
At point O, it collides with a stationary small block B with mass 2m.
After the collision, A and B immediately stick together and move to the right, smoothly sliding onto the inclined plane and rising to a height less than the height of the inclined plane.
The collision time is extremely short.
The problem asks how much heat is generated during the collision of A and B.

premise: The curved track is smooth, so mechanical energy of A is conserved while it comes down from height h.
The impact time is extremely short, no external horizontal impulse acts, so horizontal momentum is conserved.
Before the collision, K₁ = ½ m v₁² = ½ m(2gh) = mgh
Immediately after the collision (A and B have stuck together, total mass 3m), K₂ = ½ (3m) v₂² = ½ (3m) (v₁/3)² = ½ (3m) (v₁² /9) = ⅓ · ½ m v₁² = ⅓ mgh
The loss of mechanical (kinetic) energy during this perfectly inelastic collision appears as internal energy (heat). Q = K₁ – K₂ = mgh – ⅓ mgh
